file_metadata.title: Self-Amputating and Interfusing Machines

chunks.text: Biological organisms adapt through morphology-shifting mechanisms like self-amputation, regeneration, and collective behavior. Reptiles, crustaceans, and insects amputate appendages in response to threats, while ants temporarily fuse for collective behaviors like bridge building. Morphological editing involves mass addition and subtraction, linking to modular robotics where synthetic body morphology is revised by rearranging parts. This work describes a reversible cohesive interface made of thermoplastic elastomer for strong attachment and easy detachment of distributed soft robot modules without direct human handling. The reversible joint has a modulus similar to materials used in soft robotics, allowing distribution throughout soft robot bodies without mechanical incongruities. Two embodiments demonstrate utility: a self-amputating soft quadruped robot and a cluster of three fusing soft-crawling robots.
chunks.chunk_summary: This work presents a reversible cohesive interface for soft robot modules, enabling self-amputation and interfusion, inspired by biological morphology-shifting mechanisms.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Biological organisms adapt their morphology and control policy to changing tasks and environments. Self-amputation (autotomy) and dynamic aggregation (interfusion) are striking examples. Autotomy allows animals to amputate appendages to escape danger, like lizards shedding tails or crabs shedding injured appendages. Dynamic aggregation in insects, especially ants, enables collective behaviors like bridge formation or floating by rearranging mechanical connections. Both autotomy and aggregation involve mass subtraction or addition, with subtractive inspirations often overlooked in synthetic systems. A key feature enabling these adaptations is the ability to form and break connections within and between bodies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological organisms, particularly through autotomy and dynamic aggregation, demonstrate the importance of reversible connections for morphological adaptation, inspiring similar capabilities in synthetic systems.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Biological autotomy involves actively adjusting tensile strength along a predetermined fracture plane connecting extremities to the body. Animals lacking control of this plane cannot autotomize.  Modular robotics offers reversible connections for rigid materials, enabling adaptive body configurations. Soft robots also promise adaptability, and the intersection of soft and modular robotics requires soft reversible joints that don't interfere with body compliance. Many connectors for soft robots rely on mechanical forces like metal pins, plastic sockets, screws, and push fittings, offering high strength but requiring precise alignment and manual handling. These rigid materials reduce overall flexibility and compliance.
chunks.topic: Reversible connections in biology and robotics
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological autotomy relies on controlled fracture planes, while modular robotics, especially in the soft domain, requires compliant, reversible joints for adaptable configurations.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Magnetic forces, using permanent magnets embedded in soft bodies, enable strong connections but introduce rigidity and weight. Magnetic force modulation is challenging, and large forces often require manual manipulation. Electromagnets offer reversible force but share rigidity and weight issues, limiting application to rigid modular robots. Electrostatic force between conductive membranes under high voltage is weak, suitable only for light modules. Micro-patterned dry adhesives based on van der Waals interactions are relatively weak and directional, requiring manual detachment. Hot-melt adhesives and stimuli-responsive hydrogels offer reversible adhesion but lack cool-state compliance, applicability to non-conductive materials, or rapid reversibility, respectively.
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing soft robot connection methods, including magnetic, electrostatic, and adhesive approaches, have limitations in strength, compliance, reversibility, or applicability to various materials.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: This work introduces a thermally responsive thermoplastic elastomer for attaching and detaching soft robot components. The design requirements include tunable bonding strength, many attach/detach cycles without performance degradation, and compliance matching common soft robotics materials. Using a bicontinuous thermoplastic foam (BTF) structure, the formulation and geometry are optimized for these requirements. The utility of the reversible joint is demonstrated in autotomizing and interfusing soft robot demonstrations.
chunks.topic: Novel reversible joint for soft robots
chunks.chunk_summary: A novel thermally responsive thermoplastic elastomer joint is presented, addressing the need for tunable, durable, and compliant reversible connections in soft robotics.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: A temperature-modulated reversible joint is achieved using a bicontinuous thermoplastic foam (BTF) structure. Styrene-isoprene block copolymer (SIS), rubbery at room temperature and liquid at high temperature, is used. SIS is plasticized with paraffin oil to lower modulus and melting point, matching common soft robotics silicones. A bicontinuous foam structure of SIS scaffold infused with silicone matrix allows SIS to melt and combine cohesively with counterparts while adhering to the silicone matrix via mechanical bonding.  Reversible connection involves heating two BTF surfaces, melting the SIS, and allowing them to combine upon contact. Cooling solidifies the connection. Disconnection involves heating the joint to melt and weaken the SIS, allowing easy separation. Each side retains the bicontinuous structure for repeated connections.
chunks.chunk_summary: A bicontinuous thermoplastic foam (BTF) structure, composed of plasticized SIS and silicone, enables temperature-modulated reversible connections in soft robots.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The BTF joint exhibits high strength and compliance. Tensile tests show a strength of 29.5 kPa, exceeding electrostatic joints and comparable to rigid magnetic and mechanical joints. T-peel tests at room temperature show a bond strength of 68.4 kPa. Heating to 120 °C (above SIS melting point) reduces strength by over 30x to 2.1 kPa. An intermediate disconnection temperature of 65 °C yields 5.3 kPa bond strength. The similar force at 65 °C and 120 °C suggests heating above the melting point isn't always necessary for disconnection.  A rapid, monotonic decrease in peak forces is observed between 25 °C and 65 °C.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BTF joint demonstrates high strength and compliance at room temperature, with significant weakening upon heating for easy disconnection, even at temperatures below the SIS melting point.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: T-peel tests on BTF specimens with varying thickness (t) and pore size (d) reveal the influence of design parameters on bond strength. Maximum stress at 25 °C and 65 °C increases with thickness, consistent with literature on adhesive joints.  At 120 °C, maximum stress remains constant with increasing thickness, suggesting liquid-liquid interface separation force doesn't vary with bulk thickness. The ratio of bond strengths at room temperature and above Tm correlates positively with t.  A finite element model using the J-integral method shows decreasing energy release rate (G) with increasing thickness at room temperature, while at 120 °C, G increases with thickness, consistent with experimental results. Varying pore size has minimal effect on maximum stress, suggesting streamlined manufacturing is possible with larger, easier-to-incorporate particles.
chunks.topic: Effect of thickness and pore size on BTF joint strength
chunks.chunk_summary: BTF joint strength increases with thickness at lower temperatures, while pore size has minimal effect, suggesting potential for simplified manufacturing.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Cyclic tests evaluate BTF joint performance under repeated connection/disconnection and loading. Repeated "heat-connect-cool-heat-disconnect" cycles show decreasing ultimate strength but retaining 67% of pristine strength after 150 cycles.  Most deterioration occurs within the first 50 cycles, with slower degradation thereafter. Extrapolation suggests 50% strength retention at around 250 cycles, sufficient for most soft modular robots given infrequent morphological adaptation needs. Repeated loading at room temperature with fixed displacement shows decreasing holding force with increasing cycles. At 14 mm displacement (initial maximum peel load), holding force drops to 40% and 25% after 50 and 200 cycles, respectively. Smaller displacements also weaken the joint under high cycle numbers.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BTF joint demonstrates reasonable cyclic performance, retaining significant strength after repeated connection/disconnection and loading cycles.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: A soft quadruped robot with BTF joints and flexible copper heaters demonstrates self-amputation. Under normal conditions, the robot walks forward. When pinned under a heavy object, it self-amputates a limb by heating the joint and escapes as a three-legged robot. This demonstrates on-demand joint utility for adaptability and autonomy in hazardous environments.  Joint robustness tests with soil and water exposure show minimal strength decrease (6% after soil, 20% after water), demonstrating suitability for real-world environments.
chunks.chunk_summary: A soft quadruped robot demonstrates self-amputation using BTF joints, showcasing adaptability and robustness in challenging environments.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: A group of soft crawlers with BTF joints demonstrates interfusion for collaborative tasks. Single crawlers can locomote on flat ground but fail to cross a wide crevice.  Three crawlers interfuse by lining up and heating their joints to connect. The connected crawlers collectively cross the gap using their combined length. After crossing, the joints are heated to detach, and the modules separate. This demonstrates how reversible joints enable independent and collective behaviors, allowing editable anatomy and continued task performance even after separation, showcasing dynamic plasticity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Soft crawlers demonstrate collaborative gap crossing through interfusion using BTF joints, highlighting the benefits of reversible connections for collective robotics.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Reversible joints are key to shape-based adaptations in biological organisms. Self-amputation and dynamic aggregation demonstrate the importance of reversible joints for individual and collective survival.  Soft artificial systems with reversible joints have potential for shape change via mass addition and subtraction. This work presents the first fully soft reversible joint, enabling self-amputation and interfusion in robots.  These synthetic systems can inform understanding of algorithms used by multiscale natural biological systems with dynamic structure, size, and composition changes, such as embryonic morphogenesis, metamorphosis, remodeling, and cancer.
chunks.chunk_summary: Reversible joints are crucial for biological adaptation, and this work's fully soft reversible joint enables similar capabilities in robots, potentially informing understanding of dynamic biological systems.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The reversible joint exhibits high strength (68.4 kPa) at room temperature, exceeding benchmark compliant joints while maintaining similar compliance to the robot body. At 65 °C, strength decreases significantly for easy detachment.  Repeated connection/disconnection over 250 cycles maintains over 50% of original strength. The joint doesn't require precise alignment. A 1.5 mm thick, 1 cm² BTF requires ≈400 J for (dis)connection, promising untethered operation.  The joint enables self-amputation for escape and interfusion for gap crossing, demonstrating autonomy and interfusion as promising survival mechanisms for soft robots in variable environments.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BTF joint's high strength, easy detachment, cyclic stability, and low energy requirements enable novel functionalities like self-amputation and interfusion in soft robots.
chunks.authors: ["Bilige Yang", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Stephanie J. Woodman", "Eugene Thomas", "Liana G. Tilton", "Michael Levin", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The reversible joint is fabricated using plasticized styrene-isoprene block copolymer (SIS) and paraffin oil to lower the melting point.  Open-cell SIS foam is created using sacrificial sugar particles, which are later dissolved.  The SIS foam is infused with silicone to create the bicontinuous thermoplastic foam (BTF).  T-peel and cyclic tests are conducted using a materials testing machine and a heat gun.  Copper coils embedded in the soft robots heat the joints for connection and disconnection.
chunks.chunk_summary: The BTF joint is fabricated using plasticized SIS, sacrificial sugar particles, and silicone, and its mechanical properties are tested using a materials testing machine and heat gun.
